p: C. H. HANFORD, a witness called on behalf of the Respondent, after being duly sworn, testified as follows:
Q. [Gilman] Mr. Hanford, do you know the petitioner in this case, Alice McKay? A. Yes sir.
Q. How long have you known her? A. Something like six or seven years.
Q. Do you know what her character is as a law abiding woman and as a temparate woman?
RONALD: We object to that.
The COURT: Do you mean her public reputation?
GILMAN: I intended to prove both.. I do not know that I can prove any specific acts by Mr. Hanford.
The COURT: You ask then simply if he knows her general reputation as a law abiding citizen.
Q. Do you know what her general reputation is as a law abiding woman and as a temperate woman?
Mr. RONALD: At the present time?
The COURT: It is in the present tense that the question is asked.
A. Well, jus tat the present time I do not think I know much about her reputation, within the last year I have not known much about her or her reputation.
Q. Do you know what it was prior to that time?
Mr. RONALD: We object.
A. Yes.
Q. What was it?
Mr. Ronald: We except.
A. I cannot say I know as to temperance, but as to her being a law breaker I know her reputation.
Q. What was it? A. It is bad. Persistent, troublesome violater of the law.
Q. In 1883-4 you were assistant district attorney were you not? A. Yes sir.
Q. Did you ever have occasion to prosecute this woman? A. I did.
Q. When? A. It was in the fall of 1883 at Tacoma.
Q. For what offense?
RONALD: We object it is immaterial.
The COURT: Objection overruled and exception noted.
A. For selling spiritous liquors to Indians.
Q. With what result?
RONALD: We object.
The COURT: I presume there is better evidence.
Gilman: In the short time I have had I have not had time to get the record in Tacoma to introduce that. We will offer to prove the conviction of the defendant.
CROSS-EXAMINATION:
Q. [RONALD] How many times do you know of her being arrested for assault and battery? A. I dont remember any specific acts of being arrested for assault and battery.
Q. Do you know of her being arrested except that one time? that you prosecuted her Mr. Hanford, of your own personal knowledge? A. Not of my own personal knowledge.
Q. That is the only time that you knew of her violating any law? A. Yes, of my own knowledge.
Q. The fact is the jury hung in that case? A. no sir.
REDIRECT EXAMINATION:
Q. [Gilman] What is the fact? [I think I am entitled to it as he has gone into the question]
Mr. RONALD: We object I would not have been allowed to ask that question.
The COURT: I will hear the answer, but I will strike it out myself if I change my mind about it.
Q. What was the verdict? A. She plead guilty, there was no jury called.

RONALD: It is not a fact that you suspended sentence because she was under duress and force to do so by her husband? A. No sir, that was not the case. There has naver been a judgement in the case, the Court suspended sentence.
GILMAN: For what cause?
RONALD: We object.
The COURT: Objection overruled, exception allowed.

A. Because she appeared in Court with twi small children and made an appeal to the court that it would be a great hardship to send her to the Penitentiary on McNeal's island, where there was no provision made for the keeping of a
